p: A. princeps belongs to the family Asteraceae, and its leaves have been used from years for the management of dysmenorrhea, infertility, and other endometriosis-related complaints. This medicinal plant contains a wide range of bioactive compounds such as flavonoids, terpenoids, sterolic acids, and coumarins [ 146]. It has been reported to have antitumor, antioxidant, antispasmodic, antihemorrhagic, and antiulcerogenic effects [ 4].
